1. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially experienced respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia and secretions. He underwent successful extubation but required a tracheostomy due to increased work of breathing, upper airway obstruction, worsening ability to cough, no gag reflex, rhonchi increasing, and worsening WOB (work of breathing) and tachypnea. The patient's breathing improved post trach.

2. Lower Left Lobe Pneumonia: A chest x-ray from [**10-3**] showed a new LLL pneumonia. The sputum culture preliminary results indicate MR [First Name (Titles)] [Last Name (Titles)]. The patient is being treated with vancomycin for a total of 15 days. Aggressive pulmonary toileting/chest PT, nebs, saline spray, and post op trach care as per ENT are also recommended. The tracheostomy will be changed on POD #5.

3. Anemia: The patient's HCT (hematocrit) has trended down over the course of his hospitalization, with today's HCT being 20.8. A type and screen will be done, and the patient will receive a transfusion of 1 unit

   transferred from oncology service for hypoxic respiratory distress.
   # Respiratory failure: Initially likely secondary to PNA and secretions

   GNR.  Also had MSSA in sputum.  For which he completed a full course of
   antibiotics (levofloxacin, cefepime, vancomycin).  Patient had a
   tracheostomy done on [**10-2**] for increased work of breathing due to upper
   airway obstruction, worsening ability to cough (likely cannot close
   glottis), no gag reflex, rhonchi increasing, and worsening WOB and
   tachypnea, with significantly improved breathing post trach.  Chest
   x-ray from [**10-3**] showed a new LUL pneumonia, sputum culture MR [**First Name (Titles) **]
[**Last Name (Titles) 10549**]eus
   - PNA being treated with vanc for a total of 15 days

   - Post op trach care as per ENT
 will change trach on POD #5; likely

   pressures
   # Anemia: HCT has trended down over the course of his hospitalization,

s, no current signs of active bleeding, likely due to

   - continue to guaiac stools

   - airway secure now with trach in place

   .

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of stage III squamous cell throat cancer, admitted for respiratory failure. He was transferred from the oncology service and had completed a full course of antibiotics for MRSA. The patient underwent a tracheostomy on 10/2 due to increased work of breathing and upper airway obstruction. Chest x-ray showed a new left upper lobe pneumonia, and sputum culture grew MRSA.

Assessment and plan:
1. Respiratory failure: Initially likely secondary to PNA and secretions, successfully extubated on 9/26. Initial sputum culture grew GNR. Also had MSSA in sputum. For which he completed a full course of antibiotics (levofloxacin, cefepime, vancomycin). The patient had a tracheostomy done on 10/2 for increased work of breathing due to upper airway obstruction, worsening ability to cough (likely cannot close glottis), no gag reflex, rhonchi increasing, and worsening WOB and tachypnea, with significantly improved breathing post trach. Chest x-ray from 10/3 showed a new LUL pneumonia, sputum culture MR [First Name (Titles)] [Last Name (Titles)]. PNA being treated with vanc for a total of 15 days. Aggressive pulmonary toileting/chest PT. Continue nebs, saline spray. Screening for pulmonary rehab pending. Post

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of stage III squamous cell throat cancer, who was admitted for hypoxic respiratory distress. He had completed a full course of antibiotics for MSSA and GNR infections. The patient underwent a tracheostomy on 10/2 due to increased work of breathing and upper airway obstruction. A new left upper lobe pneumonia was noted on chest x-ray. The sputum culture grew MRSA. The patient's HCT has trended down over hospitalization, so he received a transfusion of 1 unit PRBC. He also has metabolic alkalosis, leukocytosis, stage III squamous cell throat CA, hypertension, hyponatremia, h/o CVA, and depression. The patient's current medications include pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and atenolol. His current vital signs are as follows: Tmax 38.2°C (100.7°F), Tcurrent 37.4°C (99.4°F), HR 79 bpm (75-98 bpm), BP 139/57 mmHg (77-164/40-83 mmHg), RR 23 breaths/min (18-31 breaths/min), SpO2 100%. The patient's physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, tracheostomy in place with thick yellow secretions, clear lung fields bilaterally, g-tube in place,

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, pneumonia, and oropharyngeal cancer. He has anemia and MRSA growing from sputum cultures. The patient received blood transfusions yesterday and has shown improvement in his Hct levels. He is currently on various medications including vancomycin for MRSA, heparin for prophylaxis, and other ICU medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.2 C, heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 118/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's physical examination is unremarkable except for right lower extremity edema. His laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL and leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 18.2 K/uL. His electrolytes are within normal limits, but he has a slightly elevated creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL. The patient's medical complications include ineffective airway clearance, impaired balance, impaired muscle performance, impaired ventilation, hypoxemia, and acute respiratory failure. The plan is to continue vancomycin for MRSA and start physical therapy. The patient's tracheostomy tube will be changed to a smaller size to enable him to use a P-M valve for speaking. His Hct level

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of stage III squamous cell throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. He had completed a full course of antibiotics for pneumonia (PNA) and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). A tracheostomy was performed on 10/2 due to increased work of breathing and upper airway obstruction. Chest x-ray showed a new left upper lobe pneumonia. The patient is currently being treated for PNA with vancomycin for a total of 14 days. He requires aggressive pulmonary toileting, chest physical therapy, nebulizers, and saline spray. The patient's hemoglobin concentration (HCT) has been trending down, but with no active signs of bleeding or positive guaiac test, indicating that the anemia could be due to repeated phlebotomy and ongoing inflammation suppressing his bone marrow. The patient also has facial swelling, white-yellow tongue plaques, metabolic alkalosis, leukocytosis, stage III squamous cell throat cancer, hypertension, hyponatremia, history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA), and depression. He is currently on various medications including atenolol, lisinopril, ASA, and an antidepressant. The patient's current vital signs are stable, and he is expected to continue receiving ICU care until he is ready for pulmonary rehabilitation placement.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's dependence on respiratory support and the presence of thick yellow secretions suggest a risk of continued respiratory failure.

3. Anemia: The patient's decreasing HCT levels indicate the need for further evaluation and management of anemia.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is on the hypertensive side, requiring careful monitoring and potential

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of stage III squamous cell throat cancer, admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. He was transferred from the oncology service and initially had respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia (PNA) and secretions. The patient underwent successful extubation on [**9-26**]. His initial sputum culture grew out Gram-negative rods (GNR), and he also had methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) in the sputum. He completed a full course of antibiotics (levofloxacin, cefepime, vancomycin).

The patient had a tracheostomy performed on [**10-2**] due to increased work of breathing, worsening ability to cough, lack of gag reflex, rhonchi increasing, and worsening work of breathing (WOB) and tachypnea. His breathing improved post trach. A chest x-ray from [**10-3**] showed a new left upper lobe pneumonia. The patient's sputum culture grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

The patient is currently being treated for PNA with vancomycin for a total of 14 days. He is also receiving aggressive pulmonary toileting/chest physical therapy (PT), nebulizers with saline spray, and is being screened for pulmonary rehab. The tracheostomy will be changed on POD #
